body.p: This page documents library components that provide metaprogramming sorts of functionality. For the most part they are useful for putting design by contract checks into code or doing various kinds of clever things with templates.

For example, you might have a templated function that is templated on a type T and you want to make sure that T is either a char or wchar_t type. You could place the following into your code and it would cause the compile to error out when T was set to something other than char or wchar_t.
static_assert(is_same_type<T,char>::value || is_same_type<T,wchar_t>::value, "Should be a char type");

component.name: tmin
component.description: This is a template to compute the min of two values at compile time.

component.name: tmax
component.description: This is a template to compute the max of two values at compile time.

component.name: compile_time_integer_list
component.description: This is a variadic template that can represent a list of integers.

component.name: make_compile_time_integer_range
component.description: This is a variadic template that takes one number, MAX, as input and creates a compile_time_integer_list representing the range of integers [1,MAX] inclusive.

component.name: tabs
component.description: This is a template to compute the absolute value a number at compile time.

component.name: unsigned_type
component.description: This is a template that allows you to obtain the unsigned version of any integral type. For example, unsigned_type<signed short>::type == unsigned short.

component.name: static_switch
component.description: To use this template you give it some number of boolean expressions and it tells you which one of them is true. If more than one of them is true then it causes a compile time error. It is useful for cases where you want to specialize a template and you want to specialize it not by the type of object it gets per say but instead according to the values of some type traits associated with the various template arguments. A simple example of this can be seen in the assign_pixel's implementation which can be found at the bottom of the dlib/pixel.h file.

component.name: enable_if
component.description: This is a family of templates from the Boost C++ libraries that makes it somewhat easier to control template specialization. For the details see this page. Note that the header dlib/enable_if.h brings these templates into the dlib namespace.

component.name: noncopyable
component.description: This is a simple class that makes it easy to declare a non-copyable object. To use it to make your own class non-copyable just inherit from it.

component.name: is_convertible
component.description: This is a template that can be used to determine if one type is convertible into another type.

component.name: is_complex
component.description: This is a template that can be used to determine if a type is a specialization of std::complex.

component.name: is_same_type
component.description: This is a template where is_same_type<T,U>::value == true when T and U are the same type and false otherwise.

component.name: is_float_type
component.description: This is a template where is_float_type<T>::value == true when T is a floating point type (i.e. float, double, or long double) and false otherwise.

component.name: is_same_object
component.description: This is a templated function which checks if both of its arguments are actually references to the same object. It returns true if they are and false otherwise.

component.name: is_function
component.description: This is a template where is_function<T>::value == true when T is a function type.

component.name: is_signed_type
component.description: This is a template where is_signed_type<T>::value == true when T is a signed scalar type and false when it is an unsigned scalar type.

component.name: is_unsigned_type
component.description: This is a template where is_unsigned_type<T>::value == true when T is an unsigned scalar type and false when it is a signed scalar type.

component.name: is_directed_graph
component.description: This is a template where is_directed_graph<T>::value == true when T is a directed_graph object.

component.name: is_built_in_scalar_type
component.description: This is a template where is_built_in_scalar_type<T>::value == true when T is a built in scalar type such as int, char, float, etc.

component.name: promote
component.description:
This is a template that takes one of the built in scalar types and gives you another scalar type that should be big enough to hold sums of values from the original scalar type. The new scalar type will also always be signed.
For example, promote<uint16>::type == int32

component.name: remove_cvref_t
component.description:
This is a template that takes a type and strips off any const, volatile, or reference qualifiers and gives you back the basic underlying type.
For example, remove_cvref_t<const int&>::type == int

component.name: is_std_vector
component.description: This is a template where is_std_vector<T>::value == true when T is a std_vector_c or std::vector object.

component.name: is_pair
component.description: This is a template where is_pair<T>::value == true when T is a std::pair object.

component.name: is_matrix
component.description: This is a template where is_matrix<T>::value == true when T is a matrix object or some kind of matrix expression.

component.name: is_config_reader
component.description: This is a template where is_config_reader<T>::value == true when T is a config_reader or config_reader_thread_safe object.

component.name: is_graph
component.description: This is a template where is_graph<T>::value == true when T is a graph object.

component.name: is_array2d
component.description: This is a template where is_array2d<T>::value == true when T is an array2d object.

component.name: is_array
component.description: This is a template where is_array<T>::value == true when T is an array object.

component.name: is_rand
component.description: This is a template where is_rand<T>::value == true when T is a rand object.

component.name: is_reference_type
component.description: This is a template where is_reference_type<T>::value == true when T is a reference type and false otherwise.

component.name: is_const_type
component.description: This is a template where is_const_type<T>::value == true when T is a const type and false otherwise.

component.name: is_pointer_type
component.description: This is a template where is_pointer_type<T>::value == true when T is a pointer type and false otherwise.

component.name: And
component.description: This template takes a list of bool values and yields their logical and. E.g. And<true,true,true>::value == true And<true,false,true>::value == false

component.name: Or
component.description: This template takes a list of bool values and yields their logical or. E.g. Or<true,true,true>::value == true Or<true,false,true>::value == true Or<false,false,false>::value == false

component.name: are_nothrow_copy_assignable
component.description: A type trait class telling you if all the types given to it are no-throw copy assignable.

component.name: are_nothrow_copy_constructible
component.description: A type trait class telling you if all the types given to it are no-throw copy constructable.

component.name: are_nothrow_move_assignable
component.description: A type trait class telling you if all the types given to it are no-throw move assignable.

component.name: are_nothrow_move_constructible
component.description: A type trait class telling you if all the types given to it are no-throw move constructable.

component.name: are_nothrow_swappable
component.description: A type trait telling you if a list of types are all no-throw swappable.

component.name: callable_traits
component.description: This traits class gives will tell you about the various properties of a function or otherwise callable type. Like what it returns, how many arguments it has, and so forth.

component.name: conjunction
component.description: Takes a list of type traits and gives you the logical AND of them.

component.name: is_any_type
component.description: This is a template that tells you if a type appears in a list of other types.

component.name: is_byte
component.description: Tells you if a type is one of the C++ byte types (e.g. is is T a char?).

component.name: is_complete_type
component.description: Tells you if a type is a complete type.

component.name: is_detected
component.description: This is a convenient tool for testing if a type has some arbitrary property. E.g. you could check if a class type has some particular member function or not.

component.name: is_nothrow_swappable
component.description: A type trait telling you if a type can be swapped by a global swap() function.

component.name: is_swappable
component.description: A type trait telling you if a type can be swapped by a global swap() function that is declared noexcept.

component.name: nth_type
component.description: This is a type trait for getting the n'th argument of a parameter pack. In particular, nth_type<n, some_types...>::type is the nth type in some_types.

component.name: size_
component.description: This is a shorthand for making std::integral_constant of type size_t.

component.name: types_
component.description: Just a list of types.

component.name: void_t
component.description: Just always the void type. Is useful in SFINAE expressions when the resulting type doesn't matter and you just need a place to put an expression where SFINAE can take effect.

description.p: This is a macro function for debugging. Its form is ASSERT_ARE_NOT_SAME_TYPE(type1, type2). If type1 and type2 are the same type then the compile will fail. This is sometimes useful in validating template arguments.

This is a macro function for debugging. Its form is ASSERT_ARE_SAME_TYPE(type1, type2). If type1 and type2 are not the same type then the compile will fail. This is sometimes useful in validating template arguments.

component.name: DLIB_ASSERT_HAS_STANDARD_LAYOUT
component.description:
This macro is meant to cause a compiler error if a type doesn't have a simple memory layout (like a C struct). In particular, types with simple layouts are ones which can be copied via memcpy().
This was called a POD type in C++03 and in C++0x we are looking to check if it is a "standard layout type". Once we can use C++0x we can change this macro to something that uses the std::is_standard_layout type_traits class. See: http://www2.research.att.com/~bs/C++0xFAQ.html#PODs

component.name: DLIB_MAKE_HAS_MEMBER_FUNCTION_TEST
component.description:
The DLIB_MAKE_HAS_MEMBER_FUNCTION_TEST() macro is used to define traits templates that tell you if a class has a certain member function. For example, to make a test to see if a class has a public method with the signature void print(int) you would say:
DLIB_MAKE_HAS_MEMBER_FUNCTION_TEST(has_print, void, print, (int))
Then you can check if a class, T, has this method by looking at the boolean value:
has_print<T>::value
which will be true if the member function is in the T class.

description.p: This is a macro function that is identical to the DLIB_ASSERT macro except that it is always enabled. Even if _DEBUG, DEBUG and ENABLE_ASSERTS are not defined.

Note that when this macro fails and throws an exception it also calls the global C function dlib_assert_breakpoint(). This behavior makes it easy to set a debugging tool to break when DLIB_CASSERT fails by setting a breakpoint on dlib_assert_breakpoint().

This is a macro function for debugging. Its form is DLIB_ASSERT(condition that should be true, error message) or you can omit the error message and call it like: DLIB_ASSERT(condition that should be true) If the condition is false DLIB_ASSERT throws an exception of type dlib::fatal_error with fatal_error::type == EBROKEN_ASSERT. An error message detailing the nature of the problem is stored in the member variable info which is of type std::string. Look in the following file for more details. The exception classes are defined here.
This macro is only enabled if _DEBUG, DEBUG or ENABLE_ASSERTS is defined. Also, if this macro is enabled then ENABLE_ASSERTS will be defined even if you didn't define it.

Note that when this macro fails and throws an exception it also calls the global C function dlib_assert_breakpoint(). This behavior makes it easy to set a debugging tool to break when DLIB_ASSERT fails by setting a breakpoint on dlib_assert_breakpoint().

This is a preprocessor macro that allows you to tag a function so that dlib will keep track of it in a function call stack. That is, you will be able to see a stack trace by calling get_stack_trace if you put this macro at the top of your functions.

This macro is only enabled if DLIB_ENABLE_STACK_TRACE is defined. If it isn't defined then this macro doesn't do anything. Also note that when this macro is defined it will cause DLIB_ASSERT and DLIB_CASSERT to include a stack trace in their error messages.

component.name: DLIB_STACK_TRACE_NAMED
component.description:
This is a preprocessor macro just like DLIB_STACK_TRACE except that it allows you to supply your own string to use as the function name in the stack trace instead of the one deduced by DLIB_STACK_TRACE.
This macro is only enabled if DLIB_ENABLE_STACK_TRACE is defined.

component.name: get_stack_trace
component.description:
This function allows you to query the current stack trace.
This macro is only enabled if DLIB_ENABLE_STACK_TRACE is defined.

component.name: _dT
component.description: This is a macro function for converting a string/character literal to either a char or wchar_t literal. Its form is _dT(target character type,string or character literal)

description.p: This function assigns its argument the value of 0 if it is a built in scalar type according to the is_built_in_scalar_type template. If it isn't a built in scalar type then it does nothing.
This function is useful for suppressing compiler warnings about uninitialized types inside of templates that are designed to accept the built in types as well as user defined classes.

component.name: portability_macros
component.description: This file #defines various macros depending on the platform being compiled under. See the file itself for the specifics.
